abstract_sentences.1: Lexical features are a major source of information in state-of-the-art coreference resolvers.
abstract_sentences.2: Lexical features implicitly model some of the linguistic phenomena at a fine granularity level.
abstract_sentences.3: They are especially useful for representing the context of mentions.
abstract_sentences.4: In this paper we investigate a drawback of using many lexical features in state-of-the-art coreference resolvers.
abstract_sentences.5: We show that if coreference resolvers mainly rely on lexical features, they can hardly generalize to unseen domains.
abstract_sentences.6: Furthermore, we show that the current coreference resolution evaluation is clearly flawed by only evaluating on a specific split of a specific dataset in which there is a notable overlap between the training, development and test sets.

body_sentences.2: Coreference resolution is a set partitioning problem in which each resulting partition refers to an entity.
body_sentences.3: As shown by Durrett and Klein (2013), lexical features implicitly model some linguistic phenomena, which were previously modeled by heuristic features, but at a finer level of granularity.
body_sentences.4: However, we question whether the knowledge that is mainly captured by lexical features can be generalized to other domains.

body_sentences.9: Worse, the difference between stateof-the-art coreference resolvers and the rule-based system drops significantly when they are applied on a new dataset, even with consistent definitions of mentions and coreference relations (Ghaddar and Langlais, 2016a).
body_sentences.10: In this paper, we show that if we mainly rely on lexical features, as it is the case in state-of-theart coreference resolvers, overfitting become more sever.
body_sentences.11: Overfitting to the training dataset is a problem that cannot be completely avoided.
body_sentences.12: However, there is a notable overlap between the CoNLL training, development and test sets that encourages overfitting.
body_sentences.13: Therefore, the current coreference evaluation scheme is flawed by only evaluating on this overlapped validation set.
body_sentences.14: To ensure meaningful improvements in coreference resolution, we believe an out-of-domain evaluation is a must in the coreference literature.
body_sentences.15: 2 Lexical Features  The large difference in performance between coreference resolvers that use lexical features and ones which do not, implies the importance of lexical features.
body_sentences.16: Durrett and Klein (2013) show that lexical features implicitly capture some phenomena, e.g.
body_sentences.17: definiteness and syntactic roles, which were previously modeled by heuristic features.
body_sentences.18: Durrett and Klein (2013) use exact surface forms as lexical features.
body_sentences.19: However, when word embeddings are used instead of surface forms, the use of lexical features is even more beneficial.
body_sentences.20: Word embeddings are an efficient way of capturing semantic relatedness.
body_sentences.21: Especially, they provide an efficient way for describing the context of mentions.

body_sentences.24: Clark and Manning (2016b) capture the required information for resolving coreference relations by using a large number of lexical features and a small set of nonlexical features including string match, distance, mention type, speaker and genre features.
body_sentences.25: The main difference is that Clark and Manning (2016b) use word embeddings instead of the exact surface forms that are used by Durrett and Klein (2013).
body_sentences.26: Based on the error analysis by cort (Martschat and Strube, 2014), in comparison to systems that do not use word embeddings, deep-coref has fewer recall and precision errors especially for pronouns.
body_sentences.27: For example, deep-coref correctly recognizes around 83 percent of non-anaphoric “it” in the CoNLL development set.
body_sentences.28: This could be a direct result of a better context representation by word embeddings.
body_sentences.29: 3 Out-of-Domain Evaluation  Aside from the evident success of lexical features, it is debatable how well the knowledge that is mainly captured by the lexical information of the training data can be generalized to other domains.

body_sentences.114: 5 Discussion  We show the extensive use of lexical features biases coreference resolvers towards seen mentions.
body_sentences.115: This bias holds us back from developing more robust and generalizable coreference resolvers.
body_sentences.116: After all, while coreference resolution is an important step for text understanding, it is not an endtask.
body_sentences.117: Coreference resolvers are going to be used in tasks and domains for which coreference annotated corpora may not be available.
body_sentences.118: Therefore, generalizability should be brought into attention in developing coreference resolvers.
body_sentences.119: Moreover, we show that there is a significant overlap between the training and validation sets in the CoNLL dataset.
body_sentences.120: The LEA metric (Moosavi and Strube, 2016) is introduced as an attempt to make coreference evaluations more reliable.
body_sentences.121: However, in order to ensure valid developments on coreference resolution, it is not enough to have reliable evaluation metrics.
body_sentences.122: The validation set on which the evaluations are performed also needs to be reliable.
body_sentences.123: A dataset is reliable for evaluations if a considerable improvement on this dataset indicates a better solution for the coreference problem instead of a better exploitation of the dataset itself.
body_sentences.124: This paper is not intended to argue against the use of lexical features.
body_sentences.125: Especially, when word embeddings are used as lexical features.
body_sentences.126: The incorporation of word embeddings is an efficient way for capturing semantic relatedness.
body_sentences.127: Maybe we should use them more for describing the context and less for describing the mentions themselves.
body_sentences.128: Pruning rare lexical features plus incorporating more generalizable features could also help to prevent overfitting.
body_sentences.129: To ensure more meaningful improvements, we ask to incorporate out-of-domain evaluations in the current coreference evaluation scheme.
body_sentences.130: Outof-domain evaluations could be performed by using either the existing genres of the CoNLL dataset or by using other existing coreference annotated datasets like WikiCoref, MUC or ACE.
